question:
A company has a production web application in which users upload documents through a web interface or an API. As part of another evolution of the application, the company wants to add a new feature to process a queue of documents asynchronously.

The company needs to ensure that documents are processed at least once. The application already runs on Amazon EC2 instances in an Auto Scaling group.

A solutions architect must design a scalable and secure solution for the new feature.

Which solution meets these requirements?

options.A: Add an Amazon Simple Queue Service (Amazon SQS) queue. Configure the application to add a message to the queue when a document is uploaded. Create a new Auto Scaling group of EC2 instances that are configured to process messages from the queue.
options.B: Add an Amazon Simple Queue Service (Amazon SQS) queue. Configure the application to add a message to the queue when a document is uploaded. Configure the EC2 instances in the existing Auto Scaling group to process messages from the queue.
options.C: Add an Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose delivery stream. Configure the application to add a message to the stream when a document is uploaded. Configure the EC2 instances in the existing Auto Scaling group to process messages from the stream.
options.D: Add an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic. Configure the application to publish a message to the topic when a document is uploaded. Subscribe the EC2 instances in the existing Auto Scaling group to the topic to process messages.

explanation: SQS provides at-least-once delivery guarantee and decouples document processing from upload. A separate Auto Scaling group allows independent scaling for processing workload. SQS visibility timeout prevents multiple instances processing the same message. SNS doesn't guarantee at-least-once processing. Kinesis Firehose is for streaming data to destinations, not message queuing. Using existing ASG doesn't allow independent scaling.
